Before going to production, it's always advised to enable authentication on your MCP server trigger.

nodes.name: FileSystem MCP Server
nodes.notes: This mcpTrigger node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: ListDirectory

parameters.command: =ls /home/node/{{ $fromAI('path', 'optional, leave blank for project root directory.') }}
parameters.toolDescription: List directories under the project root folder. The project root directory is /home/node/

nodes.notes: This executeCommandTool node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: CreateDirectory

parameters.command: =mkdir -p /home/node/{{ $fromAI('filename', 'name of directory. Will be scoped under the /home/node/ project root directory. Optionally use path to create within subdirectories') }}
parameters.toolDescription: Create directories under the project root folder. The project root folder is /home/node.

nodes.notes: This executeCommandTool node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: readOneOrMultipleFiles
nodes.notes: This executeCommand node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: ReadFiles

parameters.name: readFil
parameters.description: =Call this tool to read the contents of a file. Include file extension.

nodes.notes: This toolWorkflow node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: WriteFiles

parameters.name: write_file
parameters.description: Call this tool to write contents to one or more files. Filenames and Contents are matched by their respective Array Indexes. Eg. To write to a single file, use { filenames: [<filename1>,<filename2>], contents: [<content1>,<content2>] }

value.contents: ={{ /*n8n-auto-generated-fromAI-override*/ $fromAI('contents', `An array of strings for content to be written`, 'string') }}

nodes.notes: This toolWorkflow node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: writeOneOrMultipleFiles
nodes.notes: This executeCommand node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: SearchDirectory

parameters.command: =find /home/node/ -name "{{ $fromAI('filename', 'A name search paramter for the linux find tool') }}"
parameters.toolDescription: Search the project folder for a file by name. The project root directory is /home/node/

nodes.name: Sticky Note1

## 2. Use Custom Workflow Tool for More Complex Commands

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note2

parameters.content:
## Try It Out!
### This n8n demonstrates how to build a simple FileSystem MCP server. Connecting to this server allows MCP clients and agents to list, read and create directories and files on the local machine or remote server.

This MCP example is based off an official MCP reference implementation which can be found here -{{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }}

### How it works
* A MCP server trigger is used and connected to 5 tools: 3 Execute Command tools and 2 custom workflow tools.
* The 3 Execute Command tools allow for listing, searching and creating directories. 
* The 2 custom workflow tools are for reading and writing files to disk.
* Special care has been to not allow the MCP agent to execute arbitrary linux commands on the target server. This is achieved by only allowing the agent to provide parameters such as filenames and paths rather than raw commands. 

### How to use
* This Filesystem MCP server will write to the server which hosts the n8n instance - this can be your local machine or a remove server. If your target filesystem is on neither, then modify the commands to connect to the desired server.
* Connect your MCP client by following the n8n guidelines here - {{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }}
* Try the following queries in your MCP client:
  * "Please help me list all folders under the project directory."
  * "Help me create a bash script to send a notification to Slack."
  * "Search for the log file on the 22nd April and read its contents. What was the cause of the outage?"

### Requirements
* Linux file system for this example template. Feel free to modify if working on Windows.
* MCP Client or Agent for usage such as Claude Desktop - {{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }}

### Customising this workflow
* Implement the moving and renaming of files by adding more custom workflow tools to the MCP server.
* Remember to set the MCP server to require credentials before going to production and sharing this MCP server with others!

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Workflow Documentation

parameters.content:
# Stickynote Workflow

## Overview
Automated workflow: Stickynote Workflow. This workflow integrates 7 different services: stickyNote, switch, executeCommandTool, mcpTrigger, toolWorkflow. It contains 14 nodes and follows best practices for error handling and security.

## Workflow Details
- **Total Nodes**: 14
- **Node Types**: 7
- **Error Handling**: ✅ Implemented
- **Security**: ✅ Hardened (no sensitive data)
- **Documentation**: ✅ Complete

## Node Breakdown
- **Sticky Note**: stickyNote
- **Sticky Note3**: stickyNote
- **FileSystem MCP Server**: mcpTrigger
- **ListDirectory**: executeCommandTool
- **CreateDirectory**: executeCommandTool
- **When Executed by Another Workflow**: executeWorkflowTrigger
- **Operation**: switch
- **readOneOrMultipleFiles**: executeCommand
- **ReadFiles**: toolWorkflow
- **WriteFiles**: toolWorkflow
- ... and 4 more nodes

## Usage Instructions
1. **Configure Credentials**: Set up all required API keys and credentials
2. **Update Variables**: Replace any placeholder values with actual data
3. **Test Workflow**: Run in test mode to verify functionality
4. **Deploy**: Activate the workflow for production use

## Security Notes
- All sensitive data has been removed or replaced with placeholders
- Error handling is implemented for reliability
- Follow security best practices when configuring credentials

## Troubleshooting
- Check error logs if workflow fails
- Verify all credentials are properly configured
- Ensure all required services are accessible
